31.text: Hello and welcome to the Great History Quiz.

35.text: The show where we give you, the viewer, the chance to

37.text: pit your wits against some of the country's most respected historians.

41.text: Between them, these people have got 16 university degrees,

47.text: and contributed over 200 hours of television.

52.text: Today's show is dedicated to that notorious dynasty, the Tudors,

55.text: who ruled the country from 1485 to 1603.

59.text: A turbulent period that changed the face of British history forever.

64.text: Along the way, we will taste some Tudor dishes,

69.text: and reveal some dubious medical advice and we will also

3055.text: Now, Whiskey, for a bonus question, can you tell me

3058.text: what this little animal would have been used for in a Tudor kitchen?

3063.text:
- Can I answer? 
- You can answer.

3065.text: We don't have buzzers, but you can certainly answer.

3069.text: Whiskey is supposed to be the last surviving spit dog,

3074.text: which is a kind of dog that was bred

3077.text: to have a long body and short little legs,

3079.text: so it would run about in a little wheel

3081.text: and it would stop you having to turn the spit manually.

3085.text: You're absolutely right, turn the spit with the meat on it.

3087.text: He's the Turnspit Dog. Well done.

3094.text: There is nothing about Whiskey, the little Turnspit Dog,

3099.text: You already have secured your point, but can you, or can anybody,

3103.text: tell me what might have been done -

3105.text: of really unspeakable cruelty, I have to say -

3108.text: to make little Whiskey run faster on his wheel?

3111.text: Did it involve the enema pipe?

3113.text: It didn't involve the enema pipe!

3115.text: Was there fire put under the wheel, to make him run?

3118.text: Yeah, they would throw coals onto the wheel to make him run faster,

3121.text: because his little paws were hot.

3123.text: Turnspit dogs apparently were used as feet-warmers in church on a Sunday.

3130.text: Well, thank you all for being so very game.

3133.text: After that round we can reveal that Lucy's team have 20 points

3145.text: Now it's time to play our final round.

3156.text: So finally, having spent a while looking at how the Tudors lived,

3160.text: it seems entirely appropriate that our last round

3165.text: This is a quickfire round, with questions worth a point.

3168.text: Equally, teams, I should tell you that an incorrect answer

3171.text: will result in you being deducted a point.

3174.text: Greg looks really happy at that.

3178.text: and let's play The Last Word.

3181.text: Which monarch said, "When I am dead and opened,

3187.text: That's right. "You shall find Calais lying on my heart."

3190.text: One point to you. Which Elizabethan playwright was stabbed to death

3193.text: in a pub in Deptford... BELL

3197.text: It was Christopher Marlowe, it was in a row over a bill.

3200.text: Who said that he believed the mercy of Christ

3204.text: "yea, though they were greater than can be," on his deathbed?

3209.text: I'll move on - that was Henry VIII.

3213.text: which Elizabethan statesman died from pneumonia

3218.text:
- Francis Bacon. 
- It was Francis Bacon. What was the experiment?

3221.text: He was stuffing a chicken with snow.

3223.text: He WAS stuffing a chicken with snow!

3224.text: Whose death was described as "mildly, like a lamb,

3230.text:
- Elizabeth I. 
- That's right. It was mild like a lamb,

3233.text: "easily, like a ripe apple from the tree."

3236.text: Whose body and severed head was placed in an old arrow chest

3243.text:
- That would be Anne Boleyn. 
- It was Anne Boleyn.

3246.text: "Most gracious prince, I cry for mercy, mercy, mercy."

3249.text:
- It's not working! It is. 
- BELL

3254.text: Written to Henry VIII, was the end of that question.

3258.text: Whose wife, named Elizabeth, is said to have carried his severed head

3266.text: Carried his severed head in a bag for 29 years.

3270.text: at the funeral of Henry's widow Catherine Parr?

3274.text:
- Was it Elizabeth? 
- No, it wasn't.

3276.text:
- It was Lady Jane Grey, you lose a point. 
- Sorry.

3278.text: For which monarch were two funeral services held,

3285.text:
- Edward VI. 
- It was Edward VI. Next question. How was Richard Roose,

3288.text: the cook of the Bishop of Rochester, executed?

3293.text: He was boiled alive for two hours, apparently.

3299.text: Well, that sound signals the end of the round

3302.text: and indeed, the end of the quiz.

3305.text: I can tell you that Lucy's team have 25 points

3321.text: So Dan's team get the silver Tudor groats,

3323.text: and I'm afraid that Lucy's team, it's off to the Tower for you,

3328.text: The only thing left to do, then,

3330.text: is to pay one last visit to our Tudor timeline.

3333.text: Here it is. Full of the people and events that have made this

3338.text: one of the most remarkable periods in British history.

3353.text: Thank you to our wonderful historians, Lucy, Greg and Kate,

3361.text: I'd like to thank all of you for watching,

3364.text: and in the words of that great Elizabethan, William Shakespeare,

3372.text: and then put out the light. Goodnight.
